Biofuels drive food prices higher
 by Nick Louth
 April 26 2007
 The global drive to put biofuels in our petrol tanks is pushing food prices up. As farmers across the western world grow more crops for turning into bio-ethanol and bio-diesel and less for food, supply is being squeezed. 
 Though touted as a way of offsetting global warming, biofuels have only had one clear effect so far, which has been send grain prices rocketing. While the British consumer has yet to notice much beyond the rising price of a loaf, the least well-off in other countries are already suffering.

 
 The article goes on to discuss the problems that this is causing in developing countries. Now, I am not foolish enough to believe that a lot of people actually care if people are starving to death in Africa. It is Africa. Starving to death is ind of what they do. They have had a lot of practice at it, evolved it to a fine art. If we actually cared, we could have stopped it decades ago.
 
 HOWEVER....there are some new components to the whole "starving in Africa" thing that, IMO, make this particularly noteworthy. The biggest one is that those starving people are attacking oil fields and pipelines in Nigeria and giving aid and comfort to Al Queda everywhere else. They have apparently stopped starving quitly and are now making noise as they starve. 
 
 IMO, turning food into fuel so mr and mrs middle class american can afford to drive their suburban to McDonalds is just a bad policy...especially if when they get there they cannot afford to supersize their extra value meal because buns cost $2 each. 
 
 It will not take too long for the American lower class to start suffering from the same. Buried in the CPI data where nobody ever looks were some pretty damn disturbing numbers related to food price inflation. The most dusturbing was the compound annual rate for the 3 months ending in March. 7.6%. That is pretty scary. 
 
 Most large food producers buy their materials (corn, soybeans, etc...) on contract, so we have not even strated to see the tip of the iceberg yet. In the last year, the cost of corn has doubled. Soybeans are up 70%. Food producers such as Coca Cola, Tyson, and Fanestil have already taken a major hit to their bottom line. The Big Box retailers are weathering the storm a little better and absorbing some of the cost increases, but even the Might Wal Mart (tm) has admitted that they will have to slowly increase prices in order to preserve profit. For already struggling middle and lower class Americans, increased food costs coupled with increased fuel costs will be more than many can handle.
